G. Brent Barkin
postsData.content:
Post #14 for 2025
Hey, I know thatâ€™s two in a day, still playing catch up.

This article is pretty cool. Itâ€™s exactly whatdoes. In fact,did you write this article?

Interesting how different groups label these assets. Iâ€™ve heard â€œoffice-warehouseâ€ and we call them â€œflex industrial.â€ This article uses â€œsmall bayâ€ and â€œlast mile.â€

From an acquisition side, hey, I like the confusion, our group is able to secure these assets below intrinsic value because, letâ€™s be honest, they arenâ€™t always the shiniest rocks in the pond.

But they are where business is done. E-commerce, HVAC, pest control, start ups that havenâ€™t gotten to the point of being able to afford buying their own space.

And this class wasnâ€™t really being built for the last 20 years or so.

Glad to work with Grant,and the team.

Read the article and let me know what you think.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! The terminology shifts really highlight the evolving nature of these assets. Looking forward to more discussions on this topic!

postsData.name:
Remington Rawlings
Remington Rawlings
postsData.content:
Meet the team.

Extraordinary people solving extraordinary problems means doing extraordinary things.

We are built to last because ofas CTO andas Founding Engineer, together leading our engineering efforts.

We are positioned for a uniquely special product market fit withand her team as she leads product.

Behind the scenes working closely with me is, my Chief of Staff and administrative wizard.

And just this week after advising us the last year,has officially hiredas Head of Sales full-time, helping us grow.

Together as a team, we have some big announcements you'll start to see over the next few weeks as we execute on our rollout plans.

But I want to say 2 things before this snowball of progress truly takes off.

1. You won't regret living your values

We won't win because we are the smartest or the most advanced, or the most well funded, or the most connected.

We are going to impact things because we have cared about actually solving a real problem since Day 1.

Last year after Unleash, we had over $1.5 million in sales pipeline, much of it progressing to close quickly. And as I was about to close deals, I found egregious errors that led me to realize, "We gotta pull the plug."

We didn't sell software, on purpose.

This last year was a year of rebuilding following that. We made personnel changes. We redid the entire code base from end to end. We revamped our calculations.

And now, we are bulletproof.

That delay brought stress.

We still sold services.

But we demonstrated we don't trade integrity for anything at OneView.

We make impact through data-driven analysis.

That starts with our willingness to be patient and make sound decisions, or else how can we help our customers do that?

2nd point: You won't regret deeply creative thinking

As a consultancy turned productized bootstrapped startup, we have gotten "around" many norms and stipulations startups face.

We avoided big funding rounds, inflated valuations, unneeded dilution, and constant scrutiny of the plans we have been making before we "knew it cold."

Now we do, and the path has never been clearer.

We must always demand of ourselves the type of innovation we never thought was possible.

We have used every flavor of AI and technology imaginable, without yet needing certain full-time hires for unneeded things.

And already we have analysis capabilities that quite literally don't exist anywhere else in the entire market (prove me wrong, I'll show you).

What we sell next will change markets.

But the quality in that process is not just the outcome, it's the process itself.

People say the destination is the journey, which can sound like excusing failure.

For my part, I believe living our values and thinking creatively are a journey that must be taken if the ultimate destination is to be achieved.

Who is ready to come and see what we have been cooking up?

comments.commentText: Letâ€™s talk, Remington Rawlings.
Joshua Nicklin name the time and the topic man, looking forward to it!

Iâ€™ve done a lot of things in my career that Iâ€™m proud of, and Iâ€™ve worked with some amazing teams. Donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve ever been more excited, or more confident about the impact we can make. Looking forward to introducing the world the OneView!
Dave Breshears donâ€™t forget us little people on your ascentâ€¦.

postsData.commentAdded: Exciting times ahead for your team! Your commitment to integrity and creative thinking truly sets you apart. Cant wait to see whats next! ğŸš€

postsData.name:
Arpit R.
Arpit R.
postsData.content:
When I face the daily struggles of being an entrepreneur, itâ€™s often because Iâ€™m juggling multiple roles and responsibilities simultaneously.

As an entrepreneur, youâ€™re the visionary, the executor, the marketer, the accountant, and sometimes even the customer support agent. This constant context-switching, coupled with the pressure to deliver results, can make every day feel like a marathon.

Hereâ€™s what helps me manage this overwhelming chaos:

Breaking my day into focused time blocks and prioritizing tasks that align with my long-term goals.

The traditional advice of â€œjust work harderâ€ or â€œhustle 24/7â€ has not worked for me.

Hereâ€™s what has worked for me:

1) I jot down my top three priorities for the next day and schedule specific time slots for deep work.
2) Iâ€™ve realized that trying to do everything myself leads to burnout. Instead, I delegate tasks that others can handle so I can focus on high-impact activities.
3) Entrepreneurship often feels like an endless grind, but Iâ€™ve learned that taking breaks, exercising, and spending time with loved ones actually makes me more productive.

This process works because it creates structure in the chaos, reduces decision fatigue, and allows me to focus my energy where it matters most. Over time, Iâ€™ve found myself less reactive and more intentional in how I approach challenges.

As Warren Buffett famously said, â€œThe difference between successful people and really successful people is that really successful people say no to almost everything.â€

This quote resonates deeply with me because it underscores the importance of prioritization and focus, which are critical in navigating the entrepreneurial journey.

What about you? How do you handle the daily challenges of entrepreneurship? Do you have a specific strategy that works wonders for you? Letâ€™s share and grow together!
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Prioritization is key. I also find delegation crucial for avoiding burnout. Lets keep sharing our strategies for success!

postsData.content:
A friendly reminder that not everyone here needs to be selling anything on LinkedIn other than their awesome personality and their awesome vibes. 

That's my approach and it has worked quite amazingly.

We can get into buying and selling stuff after we've developed a relationship.

Hope this helps.

P.S. Fun fact: I honestly have no idea what 99.9% of people here are selling or are even doing so you can keep talking about your sales funnels, leads, and amazing value propositions, but if I don't like your personality or vibe I'm probably never going to want to speak to you or do business with you. Trust me on this one.

comments.commentText: People connect with people, not pitches. Your vibe and authenticity matter way more than your sales funnel ever will.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Building genuine connections first makes all the difference. Personality shines brighter than any pitch! ğŸŒŸ

postsData.name:
Yusuf Zakir
Yusuf Zakir
postsData.content:
This has been a rough week. Iâ€™m not going to sugarcoat it.

Many of us are worried about many things. My attention feels divided and my mind feels scrambled. Many of us feel a deep sense of loss.

Over the last several years, I have spent a lot of time and energy talking about DEI â€“ what it is and what it is not (Iâ€™m sure you can find at least several dozen articles and posts that I have written about this). Iâ€™ve entertained debates and questions and commentary. Iâ€™ve done my best to educate, in whatever small ways that I can.

Today, I donâ€™t want to do that.

Instead, I want to reach out to all of you who care about belonging, inclusion, fairness, equity, diversity â€“ there are many of you. Some of you are DEI professionals, but many of you are people who simply build these values into your daily livesâ€”your families, your communities, your workplaces.

To all of you, I want to say several things.

First, you are not alone. We are all walking this path together. Our arms are locked and we will continue to march. You may feel isolated at times. But, you do not need to do any of this on your own.

Second, stay optimistic. Do not become discouraged. This optimism need not stem from any false sense of hope; rather, it stems from the very real experiences in our communities. We have more examples than we can name. We see it in our daily lives, in the smallest acts of kindness. We see it in helping our neighbors and helping strangers. We see it every time there is a disaster or a tragedy, when people step up to serve.

Finally and most importantly, thank you. Thank you for caring and continuing to care. Thank you for not giving up. Thank you for pushing forward, not only when it is easy, but particularly when it is (and will continue to be) hard.

Stay the course.

comments.commentText: Yusuf Zakir thank you and look forward to catching up again soon. This year I am focused on community and conversation and gathering with people on how we can make impact together.
Thanks for sharing Yusuf.

postsData.commentAdded: Your words resonate deeply. Together, we can foster resilience and uplift each other in these challenging times. Thanks for your inspiring message!

postsData.name:
Hunter Deskin
Hunter Deskin
postsData.content:
How im planning on creating thoughtful, research-based openers for cold calls & cold emails using Apollo.io's new power-Ups & AI prompting features  

You know that one piece of info that helps start a conversation?

Like whether or not that company runs ads, has acquired a certain business unit, if they have certain initiatives in place, etc.

Well before, it wasn't always scalable to do that research because it would limit the number of quality conversations a rep would have per day.

Which, if you prescribe to my methodologies is the most important thing.

So i mainly used to skip on doing this research and would just ask the prospects directly instead. (still recommending this)

However, this seems to be able to at least surface relevant insights in a much more scalable way that could be plugged into my dialer flow via custom fields to make my conversations more relevant.

What're your thoughts? Let me know!

comments.commentText: Love it. Look out world.
Joshua Cruver  Good thing you and i are on the same team
Oh what a team!

Good to try. The tricky part is avoiding red oceans and false negatives. Itâ€™s hard, conceptually, to find publicly available information that safely replaces conversations as research. But â€¦ good to try. After all, your constraint is still the flow rate of reasonably targeted conversations.

Chris Beall luckily I donâ€™t have a flow rate constraint like the rest- so my new problem is relevance on the call. If someone is implementing additive and has bought 4 printers Iâ€™d rather know that going in if it was on a website article 90 days ago.

postsData.commentAdded: Excited to see how Apollo.ios new features will enhance personalized outreach! Scaling quality conversations is key. Letâ€™s chat more on this!

postsData.name:
Steve Burton.
Steve Burton.
postsData.content:
Forget Predictions it's boring: Hereâ€™s What I see working for us and our clients in #2025

Sorry to disappoint it's not throwing tech and AI at stuff (Yet)
Everyone loves to predict the future, but Iâ€™m not here to join that bandwagon. Instead, Iâ€™ll tell you whatâ€™s working based on real experience.
Strangely for us in the age of
old school seems to be making a massive comeback

will continue to be the best city in the World. Prove me Wrong !!

Meetings: Yep, you heard that right. Building communities and asking for referrals is the top way we have been growing. Shaking hands , kissing babies , eating steaks , building trust .

Who knew that
was important? My number one prediction? This isnâ€™t going out of style anytime soon; however, you do need the skill set to do it and since COVID people's competency has dropped off a cliff.

: Believe it or not, cold-calling the right people at the right time with the right message is making a massive impact. Again You need the skills to do it, and itâ€™s working wonders. use an Agency like
, or get training from my mateor failing that just do something.

-
: Make it easy for your customers to purchase. Weâ€™ve lost our way with all the sales tactics, sales tech and sales pipeline stages. What used to work and always did was working collaboratively to help buyers purchase.

Give them all the information they need, and when they need it make it easy to find it and progress again dont make things hard for your champion or potential customers to make the deal.

I useteam at's digital sales room to make this happen. Not expensive, easy to use and has a decent impact on deal velocity and close rate. EASY

Here are some stats that back up what I'm saying I've no idea how credible they are or who said them but they agree with me.

-95% of professionals believe that face-to-face meetings are essential for long-term business relationships.

-65% of businesses said that in-person trade shows were an invaluable part of their marketing strategy.

-80% of B2B sales interactions between suppliers and buyers are expected to occur in digital channels by 20251.

-Digital sales rooms can accelerate deal cycles by up to 50% by providing a centralized space for all sales-related interactions and documents.

49% of buyers prefer that initial contact be made via cold call.

57% of C-level executives and VPs list cold calling as their preferred method of being contacted.

So, there you have it. No crystal ball, no sympathy posts, no story out of tragedy, no
lists, no comment to get a free download, and no what's dead.

Just tried and true methods that are delivering results.

Let's have a good one, get out, meet people, sell stuff and save the Economy

postsData.name:
Christian Krause
Christian Krause
postsData.content:
"I'm not interested"
"Call me in 6 months"
"We already have a vendor"

Most sellers struggle with these common objections.

They try to "overcome" them instead of peeling the onion.

Every objection is an opportunit for discovery

Prospect: "I'm not interested"
You: "It sounds like you have already solved (insert relevant business problem). Mind sharing how you did it?"

Prospect: "Call me in 6 months"
You: "It sounds like something will change significantly in 6 months. Mind sharing what that is?"

Prospect: "We already have a vendor"
You: "Sounds like you are 100% happy with that vendor. Mind sharing what it is that they do great?"

What's your favorite objection?

ï¸ Repost to help your sales team use objections for discovery
 Followfor daily tips to hit your quota

comments.commentText: right on! turn those noâ€™s into valuable insights!
Ronen R. Pessar Exactly, Ronen! Every 'no' holds the potential to reveal insights that can lead to stronger strategies and better outcomes.

postsData.commentAdded: Great approach! Turning objections into conversations can reveal valuable insights. Whatâ€™s your strategy for handling pushback?
